subject: RE: [junit] assertTrue(true)
msgSnippet: ... If you make it just dependent on the key, you can then run the unit test without hitting the resource bundle. This, in turn, makes the tests faster due to
messageBody:
Cedric Beust wrote:
> > assertStringContains(e.getMessage(),
> > <exceptionReason dealing with badParameter>);
>
> I don't think it's a good idea to assert against exception
> messages since your tests will be hard to port when you
> internationalize your application. At the very least, make
> this dependent on a key and a bundle.

If you make it just dependent on the key, you can then run
the unit test without hitting the resource bundle. This, in
turn, makes the tests faster due to the lack of disk access.

You can then have _one_ test that says that the exception
can create a message if it's constructed with a key, and
another test (or similar mechanism) for ensuring that all
keys have corresponding entries in resource bundles.

(Avoiding hits to resource bundles can turn tests that take
10s to 100s of milliseconds into tests that only take
milliseconds; this adds up over time. :)
